LeadPara.Para: Top Middle East stories on Sunday:

TailParas.Para: CAIRO: Iraq and its powerful neighbour Iran were fuming over comments by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, a major broker in Middle East politics, about Iraqi civil war and Shiites' allegiance to Tehran.
BAGHDAD: Iraq's Shiite parliament bloc formed a committee to decide the fate of embattled Prime Minister Ibrahim Jaafari as deadly violence erupted on the third anniversary of Saddam Hussein's fall.

GAZA CITY: The armed wing of the governing Palestinian movement Hamas, under huge international pressure to renounce violence, vowed to avenge a weekend of Israeli strikes which has left 15 people dead.

JERUSALEM: Ehud Olmert's Kadima party, winners of last month's Israeli election, hosted talks with other factions to decide the make-up of a coalition which is set to fix the Jewish state's final borders.

JERUSALEM: Israel's government will on Tuesday declare coma-stricken Prime Minister Ariel Sharon as "permanently incapacitated" and name Ehud Olmert as his successor, a justice ministry official said.
JERUSALEM: Israel's Acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert announced that his government would boycott foreign diplomats who meet with members of the new Hamas-led Palestinian government.
BAGHDAD: US forces, using air support, killed eight suspected insurgents in an early morning assault in the vicinity of Hamaniyah, west of Baghdad, the military said.
LONDON: British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw reaffirmed his view that Iraq was not in a state of civil war, despite comments to the contrary by a number of senior Iraqi and Arab politicians.
BERLIN: The German foreign ministry said it had received a new video believed to be of two German hostages who have been held in Iraq since late January.
TEHRAN: Iran has shot down an unmanned surveillance plane in the south amid reports that the United States is planning military strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities, a press report said.
TEHRAN: Iran branded as "psychological warfare" media reports that the US military was planning air strikes to force Tehran to abandon its controversial nuclear program.
AMMAN: Jordan's opposition Islamic Action Front party (IAF) accused the authorities of detaining dozens of its members for distributing leaflets against fuel hikes.
KUWAIT CITY: The former head of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon, Rustom Ghazaleh, denied any role in the murder of former Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri.
